Uncertainty product for Vilenkin groups

Ivan Kovalyov 111Department of Mathematics, National Pedagogical Dragomanov University, Kiev, Pirogova 9, 01601, Ukraine, Elena Lebedeva 222Faculty of Applied Mathematics and Control Processes, Saint Petersburg State University, Universitetskaya nab., 7-9, Saint Petersburg, 199034, Russia; St. Petersburg Polytechnical University, Department of Calculus, Polytekhnicheskay 29, 195251, St. Petersburg, Russia
( i.m.kovalyov@gmail.com, ealebedeva2004@gmail.com)
Abstract

We study a localization of functions defined on Vilenkin groups. To measure the localization we introduce two uncertainty products U​Pλ𝑈subscript𝑃𝜆UP_{\lambda} and U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G} that are similar to the Heisenberg uncertainty product. U​Pλ𝑈subscript𝑃𝜆UP_{\lambda} and U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G} differ from each other by the metric used for the Vilenkin group G𝐺G. We discuss analogs of a quantitative uncertainty principle. Representations for U​Pλ𝑈subscript𝑃𝜆UP_{\lambda} and U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G} in terms of Walsh and Haar basis are given.

Keywords Vilenkin group; uncertainty product; Haar wavelet; modified Gibbs derivative; generalized Walsh function.

AMS Subject Classification:22B99; 42C40.

1 Introduction

An uncertainty product for a function characterizes how concentrated is the function in time and frequency domain. Initially the notion of uncertainty product was introduced for f∈L2​(ℝ)𝑓subscript𝐿2ℝf\in L_{2}(\mathbb{R}) by W. Heisenberg [6] and E. Schrödinger [12]. Later on extensions of this notion appeared for various algebraic and topological structures. For periodic functions, it was suggested by E. Breitenberger [1]. For some particular cases of locally compact groups (namely a euclidean motion groups, non-compact semisimple Lie groups, Heisenberg groups) the counterpart was derived in [11]. Uncertainty products on compact Riemannian manifolds was discussed in [4]. In [8], this concept was introduced for functions defined on the Cantor group. In this paper, we discuss localization of functions defined on Vilenkin groups.

To measure the localization we introduce a functional that is similar to the Heisenberg uncertainty product (see Definition 1). It depends on the metric used for the Vilenkin group G𝐺G. Two equivalent metrics are in common use for the group G𝐺G. So we discuss two uncertainty products U​Pλ𝑈subscript𝑃𝜆UP_{\lambda} and U​PG.𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G}. The first one is a strict counterpart of ‘‘dyadic uncertainty constant’’ introduced in [8] (see Theorems 1 and 2). Usage of another metric in the second uncertainty product allows for exploitation of a modified Gibbs derivative that plays a role of usual derivative for the Heisenberg uncertainty product. At the same time it turns out that usage of Haar basis is a good approach for evaluation of U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G} (see Theorem 3). In particular, it allows for an estimate of Fourier-Haar coefficients for functions defined on the Vilenkin group (see Corollary 2). The connection between U​Pλ𝑈subscript𝑃𝜆UP_{\lambda} and U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G} is showed in Lemma 1.

Proposition 1.

Corollary 1.

Any Haar function ψj,kνsuperscriptsubscript𝜓𝑗𝑘𝜈\psi_{j,k}^{\nu} is an eigenfunction of 𝒟αsuperscript𝒟𝛼{\cal D}^{\alpha} corresponding to the eigenvalue pj.superscript𝑝𝑗p^{j}.

Proof. The statement follows from Proposition 1 and (7). □□\Box

3 Uncertainty product and metrics

Originally, the concept of an uncertainty product was introduced for the real line case in 1927. The Heisenberg uncertainty product of f∈L2​(ℝ)𝑓subscript𝐿2ℝf\in L_{2}(\mathbb{R}) is the functional U​CH​(f):=Δf​Δf^assign𝑈subscript𝐶𝐻𝑓subscriptΔ𝑓subscriptΔ^𝑓UC_{H}(f):=\Delta_{f}\Delta_{\widehat{f}} such that

Δf2:=‖f‖L2​(ℝ)−2​∫ℝ(x−xf)2​|f​(x)|2​𝑑x,Δf^2:=‖f^‖L2​(ℝ)−2​∫ℝ(t−tf^)2​|f^​(t)|2​𝑑t,formulae-sequenceassignsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑓2subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑓2superscript𝐿2ℝsubscriptℝsuperscript𝑥subscript𝑥𝑓2superscript𝑓𝑥2differential-d𝑥assignsuperscriptsubscriptΔ^𝑓2subscriptsuperscriptnorm^𝑓2superscript𝐿2ℝsubscriptℝsuperscript𝑡subscript𝑡^𝑓2superscript^𝑓𝑡2differential-d𝑡\Delta_{f}^{2}:=\|f\|^{-2}_{L^{2}(\mathbb{R})}\int_{\mathbb{R}}(x-x_{f})^{2}|f(x)|^{2}\,dx,\quad\Delta_{\widehat{f}}^{2}:=\|\widehat{f}\|^{-2}_{L^{2}(\mathbb{R})}\int_{\mathbb{R}}(t-t_{\widehat{f}})^{2}|\widehat{f}(t)|^{2}\,dt,
xf:=‖f‖L2​(ℝ)−2​∫ℝx​|f​(x)|2​𝑑x,tf^:=‖f^‖L2​(ℝ)−2​∫ℝt​|f^​(t)|2​𝑑t,formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝑥𝑓subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑓2superscript𝐿2ℝsubscriptℝ𝑥superscript𝑓𝑥2differential-d𝑥assignsubscript𝑡^𝑓subscriptsuperscriptnorm^𝑓2superscript𝐿2ℝsubscriptℝ𝑡superscript^𝑓𝑡2differential-d𝑡x_{f}:=\|f\|^{-2}_{L^{2}(\mathbb{R})}\int_{\mathbb{R}}x|f(x)|^{2}\,dx,\quad t_{\widehat{f}}:=\|\widehat{f}\|^{-2}_{L^{2}(\mathbb{R})}\int_{\mathbb{R}}t|\widehat{f}(t)|^{2}\,dt,

where f^^𝑓\widehat{f} denotes the Fourier transform of f∈L2​(ℝ).𝑓subscript𝐿2ℝf\in L_{2}({\mathbb{R}}). It is well known that U​CH​(f)≥1/2𝑈subscript𝐶𝐻𝑓12UC_{H}(f)\geq 1/2 for a function f∈L2​(ℝ)𝑓subscript𝐿2ℝf\in L_{2}(\mathbb{R}) and the minimum is attained on the Gaussian. To motivate the definition of a localization characteristic for the Vilenkin group we note that on one hand xfsubscript𝑥𝑓x_{f} is the solution of the minimization problem

minx~​∫ℝ(x−x~)2​|f​(x)|2​𝑑x,subscript~𝑥subscriptℝsuperscript𝑥~𝑥2superscript𝑓𝑥2differential-d𝑥\min_{\tilde{x}}\int_{\mathbb{R}}(x-\tilde{x})^{2}|f(x)|^{2}\,dx,

and on another hand the sense of the sign ‘‘-’’ in the definition of ΔfsubscriptΔ𝑓\Delta_{f} is the distance between x𝑥x and xf.subscript𝑥𝑓x_{f}. So we come to the main definition.

Definition 1.

Suppose f:G→ℂ:𝑓→𝐺ℂf:G\to\mathbb{C}, f∈L2​(G)𝑓subscript𝐿2𝐺f\in L_{2}(G), and d𝑑d is a metric on G𝐺G, then a functional

U​P​(f):=V​(f)​V​(F​f), where assign𝑈𝑃𝑓𝑉𝑓𝑉𝐹𝑓 where UP(f):=V(f)V(Ff),\quad\mbox{ where }

is called the uncertainty product of a function f𝑓f defined on the Vilenkin group.

Thus, we study two uncertainty products U​Pλ𝑈subscript𝑃𝜆UP_{\lambda} and U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G} that corresponds to the metric d1​(x,y):=λ​(x⊖y)assignsubscript𝑑1𝑥𝑦𝜆symmetric-difference𝑥𝑦d_{1}(x,y):=\lambda(x\ominus y) and d2​(x,y):=‖x⊖y‖Gassignsubscript𝑑2𝑥𝑦subscriptnormsymmetric-difference𝑥𝑦𝐺d_{2}(x,y):=\|x\ominus y\|_{G}. The functional U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G} is defined as

The functional U​Pλ𝑈subscript𝑃𝜆UP_{\lambda} for functions defined on the Cantor group was introduced and studied in [8]. The following results are extended from the Cantor group to the Vilenkin group without any essential changes. So we omit the proofs.

Theorem 1.

Suppose f:G→ℂ,:𝑓→𝐺ℂf:G\to\mathbb{C}, f∈L2​(G).𝑓subscript𝐿2𝐺f\in L_{2}(G). Then the following inequality holds true

U​Pλ​(f)≥C, where ​C≃8.5×10−5.formulae-sequence𝑈subscript𝑃𝜆𝑓𝐶similar-to-or-equals where 𝐶8.5superscript105UP_{\lambda}(f)\geq C,\mbox{ where }C\simeq 8.5\times 10^{-5}.

The following Lemma shows that the functionals U​Pλ𝑈subscript𝑃𝜆UP_{\lambda} and U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G} have the same order.

Lemma 1.

Suppose f∈L2​(G)𝑓subscript𝐿2𝐺f\in L_{2}(G), then p−4​U​PG​(f)≤U​Pλ​(f)<U​PG​(f).superscript𝑝4𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺𝑓𝑈subscript𝑃𝜆𝑓𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺𝑓p^{-4}UP_{G}(f)\leq UP_{\lambda}(f)<UP_{G}(f).

Proof. It is sufficient to note that p−1​‖x‖G≤λ​(x)<‖x‖G.superscript𝑝1subscriptnorm𝑥𝐺𝜆𝑥subscriptnorm𝑥𝐺p^{-1}\|x\|_{G}\leq\lambda(x)<\|x\|_{G}. □□\Box

Taking into account Theorem 1, we conclude that U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G} has a positive lower bound. So, U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G} satisfies the uncertainty principle.

4 Uncertainty product U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G}.

In this section we concentrate on the uncertainty product corresponding to the metric d2.subscript𝑑2d_{2}. It turns out that the modified Gibbs derivative 𝒟𝒟\cal{D} plays a role of a usual derivative in this case. And since the Haar functions are the eigenfunctions of 𝒟𝒟\cal{D}, it is possible to get representation for U​PG𝑈subscript𝑃𝐺UP_{G} using the Haar coefficients.

Theorem 3.

Then

Remark 1.

Formally, it is possible to write ∫Gλ2​(x)​|F​f​(x)|2​𝑑x=∫G|f[1]​(x)|2​𝑑xsubscript𝐺superscript𝜆2𝑥superscript𝐹𝑓𝑥2differential-d𝑥subscript𝐺superscriptsuperscript𝑓delimited-[]1𝑥2differential-d𝑥\int_{G}\lambda^{2}(x)|Ff(x)|^{2}\,dx=\int_{G}|f^{[1]}(x)|^{2}\,dx and to try to represent U​Cλ𝑈subscript𝐶𝜆UC_{\lambda} in terms of eigenfunctions of the Gibbs derivative f[1]superscript𝑓delimited-[]1f^{[1]} in the case of the Cantor group. (The Gibbs derivative is defined for functions defined on the Cantor group only.) However, the Gibbs differentiation is not a local operation, that is (f​𝟙E)[1]≠f[1]​𝟙Esuperscript𝑓subscript1𝐸delimited-[]1superscript𝑓delimited-[]1subscript1𝐸(f\mathbbm{1}_{E})^{[1]}\neq f^{[1]}\mathbbm{1}_{E}, see also discussion in [10]. So, usage of Walsh functions instead of Haar basis might give interesting results for periodic functions only.

We did not found in the literature a formula expressing dj,kμsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑗𝑘𝜇d_{j,k}^{\mu} in terms of cj,kνsuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑗𝑘𝜈c_{j,k}^{\nu}. So we obtain this formula in the following lemma.

Formulas (9) and (10) allow for the following result on estimation of Fourier-Haar coefficients for functions defined on the Vilenkin group.

Corollary 2.

Then the series ∑ν=1p−1∑j∈ℤ∑k∈ℤ+|pj​cj,kν|2superscriptsubscript𝜈1𝑝1subscript𝑗ℤsubscript𝑘subscriptℤsuperscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑗𝑘𝜈2\displaystyle\sum_{\nu=1}^{p-1}\sum_{j\in{\mathbb{Z}}}\sum_{k\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+}}|p^{j}c_{j,k}^{\nu}|^{2} is convergent.
